dict.string: eight auspicious symbols that represent the qualities of enlightenment: the lotus bloom (purity), conch shell (thwarts evil), victory banner (victory over ignorance), parasol (power and protection), two fish (good fortune), endless knot (infinite wisdom), vase (abundance), and wheel (meditation and discipline)
power-hungry demonic beings frequently at war with the benevolent devatas (gods)
the true self; the essence of an individual devoid of physical trappings
ten incarnations of the god Vishnu that appear on the earth during catastrophic times to save the world from destruction

personifications of Vishnu in the form of two figures that carry his weapons: Chakrapurusha holds a discus, symbol of the god’s limitless power, and Shankapurusha has a conch shell, a horn used in battle that reminds devotees of Vishnu’s protection and liberation
depictions and narrative of Krishna as a crawling baby, often stealing butterballs or other alluring treats; important form of Krishna for the cultivation of rasa
the elder brother of Krishna and avatar of Shesha
(Song of the Lord) – a portion of the Mahabharata, written by Lord Krishna, that emphasizes performing one’s duty and fulfilling one’s destiny; among the most sacred of Hindu texts
ancient Hindu text that highlights the worship of Lord Vishnu through bhakti and dharma and describes the ten incarnations of Vishnu, with primary emphasis on Krishna
the religious practice of loving devotion; a central concept in the sacred Hindu text, the Bhagavad Gita
the Earth Goddess who is saved by Varaha, the great boar, from an evil demon who had hidden her (and the earth, itself) deep in the cosmic ocean of creation

a member of the Trimurti, a group of three gods who maintain the cosmos; the Creator of the Universe and Father of Mankind; with at least one of his four heads, he continually recites the Vedasa member of the Trimurti, a group of three gods who maintain the cosmos; the Creator of the Universe and Father of Mankind; with at least one of his four heads, he continually recites the Vedas
the overarching Hindu concepts of god in all of his/her manifestations
the most distinguished Hindu caste made up of priests and religious scholars
the ninth incarnation of Lord Vishnu and focus of the great world religion, Buddhism
ancient symbol of the sun and cycles of life; in the shape of a disc or wheel, it is a powerful weapon often wielded by Lord Vishnu; also refers to the points of energy on the human body
female attendants of deity that often bear flywhisks

symbol often associated with Vishnu; a horn used in battle that represents victory over evil and the primeval sound of creation; also signifies eternal space and elements of the universe as it unfolds from a single point to an ever-expanding infinity—a solid form that encompasses empty space
auspicious sight; the mutual ‘seeing’ of the deity and devotee as the culmination of worship through which the devotee gains blessings from the divine
the supreme female deity and universal counter-balance to the absolute power of male Hindu gods; the embodiment of shakti, the divine feminine force expressed in all female deities
a tambourine-like instrument often played by gopis while making music, dancing, and worshipping Krishna
a strict code of conduct and virtue that is in accordance with the order and harmony of the universe

a translucent, skirt-like garment, usually yellow or gold, that drapes the hips and thighs of Vishnu; it represents the inspiration of the Vedas and other sacred texts that, like Vishnu, radiate truth
the weapon associated with Vishnu symbolizing his role as divine Protector; also indicates the cycles of time in the cosmos

a sign of nobility, power, and wealth often associated with Vishnu, whose lobes are elongated through constant, bejeweled ornamentation; girls in India have their ears pierced as part of their initiation into womanhood

a musical instrument through which Krishna plays sublime music parallel to his own incomparable beauty; Krishna’s divine call that causes men and women to abandon the attachments of the world and devote themselves wholly to God

a tool used to swat away flies, often associated with Shiva and emblematic of the high status of the gods; held by servants as a sign of devotion and service; symbolizes not only the swatting away of pesky insects but also unwanted thoughts

one of the most beloved gods of Hinduism, whose elephant head was given to him when Shiva unwittingly chopped off his human head, not recognizing Ganesh as his son; the remover of obstacles whose blessing is pursued before undertaking a new or challenging endeavor

the most sacred river of Hinduism, which flows from the Himalayas through Northern Indian southeast through Bangladesh into the Bay of Bengal; considered the wellspring of all sacred waters, in which Hindus ritually bathe for remission of sins and disperse the ashes of their dead
half bird, half man deity; Vishnu’s mode of celestial transportation throughout the cosmos

twelfth-century poem that establishes Radha, Krishna’s beloved gopi, as the exemplary symbol of the soul’s longing for the divine, one’s unceasing devotion through bhakti, and the type of rasa (relationship) that all devotees should aspire to in worshiping deity

young women who deny themselves traditional mortal experiences in order to be in the youthful Krishna’s presence, tend his cows, frolic in divine play (lila), and dance for Krishna as he plays his enchanting flute; Radha is preeminent as a symbol of transcendent love and pure bhakti

Sanskrit name for teacher or master; etymology is based on the interplay of dark (gu) and light (ru); i.e., the master dispels the darkness of ignorance and enlightens the student with wisdom and knowledge

the monkey-faced god worshipped for his strength, perseverance, and devotion and believed by many to be an avatar of Shiva; aids Vishnu’s avatar, Rama, in the rescue of his beloved Sita and is characterized by courage and loyal friendship
the highest mountains in the world and a place of pilgrimage for Hindus; Shiva’s abode for meditating
the personal deity chosen by a devotee with whom he/she feels the greatest affinity during a particular time of life, dependent on individual needs and concerns at that moment
the final, tenth incarnation of Vishnu who will appear at the end of the world on his white horse to conquer all evil
philosophy that our actions and deeds will come back to us in kind, even in the next life
a precious gem in the shape of a diamond worn by Vishnu that emerged from the churning cosmic ocean of creation and is described in the Bhagavad Purana as “brilliant as a thousand suns”

the eighth and perhaps most beloved incarnation of Vishnu; the all-attractive and enchanting one who is thought to be the reincarnation of Rama; his love for his consort Radha and for his devotees, and their love for him, engenders the supreme form of bhakti
the mighty turtle and second incarnation of Vishnu who saved the nectar of immortality for the gods by heaving a mountain unto his shell

Vishnu’s consort and goddess of wealth, love, and good fortune and patroness of the Hindu festival of Diwali; like Vishnu, she came to earth to act as a preserver to mankind in the form of Sita and Radha, consorts of Rama and Krishna, respectively
the activities of the gods with their devotees and a central element of bhakti; a form of divine play particularly associated with Krishna’s nature for which he is known and adored

a sacred stone used in worship that symbolizes Lord Shiva and represents the fundamental, underlying principle of the universe, the power of the divine, and the source of all creation; indicated by an upward-pointing triangle that denotes its cosmic energy
the throne of the gods and a symbol of beauty, purity, and eternal reward
a club-like weapon associated with Vishnu and symbolic of his power and knowledge
monumental history of India’s ancient dynasties and their struggle for land and power wherein Krishna acts as advisor and chariot-driver to his friend, Arjuna, throughout their epic battles
an individual who has gained mastery over body, mind, and soul; one who is enlightened
a flower garland symbolic of victory and used as offerings during worship; various types of flowers are associated with specific gods
a flat, decorated, circular disk upon which a mystical diagram represents the universe with god at its center; used as a visual focus during worship and meditation

a sacred utterance used in meditation or worship, either spoken or sung, often from the Vedas or other sacred Hindu texts; Om is considered to be the most sacred mantra, believed by some to be an actual manifestation of God and the primordial sound of creation
similar to yoga, the path or discipline followed by a devotee that leads to salvation; the three margas are karma (action), bhakti (devotion), and jnana (knowledge)
the great fish and first incarnation of Vishnu who saved the four Vedas from the great flood
a sacred text dating from 250 – 500 CE that tells the story of Matsya, the fish, the first incarnation (avatar) of Vishnu

the ultimate goal of Hindu worship; to reunite with Brahman or cosmos, escape the cycle of reincarnation, and become one with deity; liberation through complete union with God, achieved through pure and steadfast bhakti or one of the other acknowledged paths
a type of drum used to play devotional music; often played by gopis while worshiping Krishna

an Islamic dynasty originating in central Asia that began conquering India in the sixteenth century and remained in power until 1857 when the British deposed the last Mughal emperor; brought with it the great arts and culture of Persia, which were assimilated into Indian culture

devotional icons that, once properly installed through ritual and worship, are considered the essence of that god and enable the devotee to experience darshan—the blessing of both seeing and being seen by the divine presence; most important are the eyes of the murti, which consecrate the icon once painted or incised
depictions and narrative of Krishna as a crawling baby, often stealing butterballs or other alluring treats; important manifestation of Krishna for the cultivation of rasa
a form of greeting that means, “I honor the place within you in which the entire universe dwells. We are one.”
the fourth incarnation of Vishnu, a cunning half man / half lion who defeated an evil demon king responsible for torturing followers of Vishnu
becoming liberated from the mind and body; a state of pure enlightenment; transcendence
the first original sound of creation, usually recited at the beginning and end of any prayer or Veda
mthe divine Being called the Supreme, the Absolute, or the Ultimate Reality; omnipresent, transcendent, and eternal, it is beyond all form, name, and gender

the sixth incarnation of Vishnu, the boy Rama with an ax whose penchant for fighting lead him to destroy the entire corrupt warrior caste; he consequently threw away his ax and devoted his life to paying penance for his violent actions

emblem symbolic of Krishna’s all-attractive visage and status as prince among Vishnu’s avatars; also associated with love and desire in connection with the song of the peacock sounded during its mating season (monsoon season in India)
a Hindu religious ceremony; temple worship through which God is acknowledged as the source of all blessings
collections of stories about the Trimurti (Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva) such as the Mahabharata and Ramayana
most beloved gopi of Krishna, venerated as the symbol of divine longing, transcendent love, and pure bhakti

literally “son of a king,” a patrilineal clan of India and parts of Pakistan that rose to power beginning in the ninth through eleventh centuries and were thought to be descendants of the ancient Hindu warrior class

a style of painting developed in the royal courts of Rajputana, India depicting the epics of the Hindu gods; Rajput paintings were treasured like precious jewelry and were often included in the dowries of the Rajput princesses
the seventh incarnation of Vishnu who, with his consort Sita, epitomizes the virtues of loyalty, bravery, and the loftiest notions of what it means to be a great parent, spouse, and human being
from the Mahabharata, the story of Rama, Vishnu’s seventh Avatar, and his band of devotees in their quest to rescue Rama’s wife, Sita, who had been abducted by the king of the demons
the real and present relationships with deity cultivated by devotees: friend, parent, servant, and/or lover; Krishna’s loving, playful nature is especially conducive to the cultivation of rasa

a belief commonly shared in Hinduism that the soul (atman) experiences birth, death, and rebirth into new physical bodies; mortal life is the process by which layers of karma are removed and the soul becomes pure and eternal, liberated from attachments, released from the cycle of reincarnation, and united with God (moksha)
a female attendant that plays the role of messenger, mediator, and peacemaker between Krishna and Radha when they experience conflict, particularly after a long periods of separation
the even-footed stance of Vishnu that symbolizes the balance and harmony that he exerts over the cosmos
the liturgical and philosophical language of Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism
a bowed, string instrument of Hindu classical music, often performed by Krishna in an attempt to woo and please Radha, especially after lengthy periods of being separated
the primary consort of Brahma and goddess of the arts, knowledge, and nature who can often be seen wearing a white sari and seated on a white lotus blossom or swan, symbolic of her purity
divine feminine power or strength, personified by Devi, the great goddess

an aspect of Vishnu in the form of a snake with five heads that accompanies Vishnu’s manifestations; a primordial entity that encompasses the universe and whose uncoiling activates Vishnu’s process of creation; considered a symbol of eternal cycles because of the snake’s ability to regenerate through the shedding of its skin
member of the Trimurti known as the Destroyer; an all-knowing yogi who meditates on the peaks of the Himalayas and appears in his non-representational form as a lingam, or sacred stone
an artist who creates the physical image of a god through prayer and meditation as a form of bhakti worship
the holy trinity of Hindu gods: Brahma, the Creator; Vishnu, the Preserver and Protector; and Shiva, the Destroyer or Transformer
an auspicious plant that especially pleases Vishnu and his avatar, Krishna; a holy basil that is believed to be endowed with a divine feminine force
offerings of devotees such as food, flowers, or honorific gestures deemed worthy of the deity—fanning with a peacock feather, for example
collection of Vedic texts that represent the core of Hindu philosophy concerning the nature of ultimate salvation (moksha)
fifth incarnation of Vishnu, the dwarf who cunningly defeated the king of the demons, Bali, and subjected the demons to the underworld as their abode
God’s mudra (hand gesture) that represents the bestowal of a blessing, with the hand upside down and the palm facing outward
the third incarnation of Vishnu, the great boar who saved the earth goddess, Bhudevi, along with the earth itself, from an evil demon who had hidden them deep in the cosmic ocean of creation

the hierarchal caste system of Hinduism widely practiced in India and consisting of five main divisions with thousands of subdivisions: Brahmin—scholars, religious leaders—most distinguished; Kshatriya—warriors, rulers; Vaisya—merchants, petty landowners; Sudras—peasants, artisans; Pariahs—untouchables, lowest caste
the most ancient sacred texts in Hinduism used for conducting religious rituals and prayers; written in Sanskrit, they consist of four parts: Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvaveda
depictions and narrative of Krishna as the fluting cowherd, traditionally in a jaunty stance with ankles crossed while playing the flute
celestial male knowledge bearers that often accompany deity, carry garlands of victory, and represent the bestowal of wisdom
member of the Trimurti; the Preserver of the universe often manifested in the form of ten incarnations who appear on earth during catastrophic times to save the world from destruction
a stone tablet devoted to Vishnu, used for personal worship
a forest in northern India where Krishna lived and grazed his cows along with others of his village and caste

a sacred thread worn by most gods and goddesses that represents the endowment of spiritual knowledge; also used in male Hindu rites of passage to signal a boy’s entrance into a life of duty and devotion

meaning “union,” a spiritual, mental, and physical discipline of calming the states of the mind to achieve unity with deity—more about awareness and communication than body shaping; typically three paths of yoga are considered the means to achieving release or liberation—the Path of Action (karma yoga), the Path of Devotion (bhakti), and the Path of Knowledge (jnana)
